channel.title: External Hard Drive
channel.description:
Hey, haven't posted here in a while, but had a question about external hard drives and thought this might be the place to ask...
I recently got the new macbook pro and am looking to buy a 1TB* external hard drive for it. The problem is that I'd like to be able to use it with my desktop, running Windows 7. Most externals I see say they either work on Windows or work on Mac but you can change the file system to work on the other.
1) Flash drives seem to work fine on either system that I plug them into, so why do externals have this filesystem issue?
2) Can you recommend any 1TB* external drives that would work well on Mac OSX Lion (soon to be Mountain Lion) and Windows 7? If it's not possible, could you explain what configuration of the filesystem on the drive entails? Would I need to change it every time I plug the drive into the other computer?
Thanks, Adam

item.title: External Hard Drive
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Some flash drives use FAT, which can be used by windows and mac.

I googled it for you:

- NTFS is read/write in Windows and only read in Mac OS X. install Mac Fuse + NTFS3g to add write support in Mac OS X - HFS (Mac OS Extended) is only read/write in Mac OS X. use MacDrive to add read/write to Windows.

NTFS3g is free, http://www.tuxera.com/community/ntfs-3g-download/

item.dc:creator: @DEFET DEFET
item.description:
@DEFET wrote:

1GB External Hard Drive… ehh nvm

There are programs on Mac that allow you use mount NTFS drives and allow to read and write from them, go search it up. Windows can recognize NTFS and any FAT filesystem iirc while Mac OS can only write to whatever their special filesystem is; Mac Journaled or w.e.
